Idiom (French Guianese Creole): Tout chyen ni jou'y pou mòdé.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Everyone has their moment to succeed or take revenge.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Everyone gets their turn in life.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Common across Caribbean Creole cultures; reflects belief in karma and time.
First Example Sentence: Pa moqué moun jòdi-a, paskè tout chyen ni jou’y pou mòdé.
Second Example Sentence: Ou pé ri mwen jòdi-a, mé on jou sé mwen ki ké ri.
Third Example Sentence: Manman toujou di mwen: ‘Tout chyen ni jou’y pou mòdé.’

Idiom (French Guianese Creole): Kannari pa ka oubliyé dlo ki té fè’y bouyi.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Never forget those who helped you in difficult times.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: We should always remember our helpers.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Ancestral African metaphor rooted in oral storytelling traditions of Guiana.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, French Guia: /kan.na.ʁi pa ka ub.li.je dlo ki te fè bu.ji/
First Example Sentence: Li pa janmen oubliyé moun ki té édé’y, paskè kannari pa ka oubliyé dlo ki té fè’y bouyi.
Second Example Sentence: Sa sé an bon pawòl: toujou sonjé sa moun fè pou’w.
Third Example Sentence: Granmanman ka répété sa chak fwa mwen vin ingrat.

Idiom (French Guianese Creole): Bwa ki pli dou sé li lapli ka pliyé.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: The kindest people are often the most affected by hardship.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Good people often suffer the most.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Rural agricultural metaphor tied to tropical forest imagery.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, French Guia: /bwa ki pli du se li la.pli ka pli.je/
First Example Sentence: Mwen ka di’w, bwa ki pli dou sé li lapli ka pliyé.
Second Example Sentence: I toujou soufè, paskè i ni bon kè.
Third Example Sentence: Sa sé pawòl ki ni anpil sajès adan’y.

Idiom (French Guianese Creole): Moun pa mò pou lèspri pèd.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: A person’s legacy lives on after death.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: People live through their deeds and memory.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Creole ancestral spirituality rooted in maroon heritage.
First Example Sentence: Granpapa pati, mé moun pa mò pou lèspri pèd.
Second Example Sentence: Chak fwa nou palé di li, nou fè’y viv ankò.
Third Example Sentence: Sa sé pawòl ki fè moun sonjé rasin yo.

Idiom (French Guianese Creole): Ti gouté dlo ka plen kannari.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Small efforts add up to great achievements.
First Example Sentence: Pa pè travay ti kal, ti gouté dlo ka plen kannari.
Second Example Sentence: Chak jès ka konté lè’w ni pasyans.
Third Example Sentence: Ti pasé ti, ou ké rivé gwo.

Idiom (French Guianese Creole): Sèpan pa janmen maché anlè sab san tras.
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Negated declarative sentence with prepositional phrase.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Every action leaves a trace or consequence.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Symbolic use of serpent in Guianese folklore as observer of truth.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, French Guia: /sɛ.pã pa ʒã.mɛ mã.ʃe ã.lɛ sab sã tʁas/
First Example Sentence: Pa kwè ou pé fè mal san pèsonn pa wè, sèpan pa janmen maché anlè sab san tras.
Third Example Sentence: Bondyé ka wè sa ki kaché.

Idiom (French Guianese Creole): Kok pa ka chanté si lapli pa vini.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Every event has a cause; things happen for a reason.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Rural Guianese proverb tied to agricultural prediction.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, French Guia: /kɔk pa ka ʃã.te si la.pli pa vi.ni/
First Example Sentence: Si bagay ka fèt konsa, sé paskè kok pa ka chanté si lapli pa vini.
Third Example Sentence: Granmanman té toujou di sa lè i té ka gadé syèl.

Idiom (French Guianese Creole): Ou pa pé bésé solèy épi men'w.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: You can’t stop truth or destiny from being revealed.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Creole proverb of African origin symbolizing inevitability of truth.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, French Guia: /u pa pe be.se sɔ.lɛj e.pi mɛ̃w/
First Example Sentence: Pa kité moun manti, ou pa pé bésé solèy épi men'w.
Second Example Sentence: Verité toujou parèt menm si ou kouvè’y.
Third Example Sentence: Sa sé pawòl ki fò tèlman i vré.

Idiom (French Guianese Creole): Zòryé ki sal pa ka fè bon dòmi.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: One can’t rest with guilt or unresolved issues.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: You can’t have peace of mind when your conscience isn’t clear.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Derived from domestic symbolism, widespread in Creole homes.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, French Guia: /zɔ.ʁje ki sal pa ka fè bɔ̃ dɔ.mi/
First Example Sentence: Si ou fè mal, ou pa ké dòmi byen: zòryé ki sal pa ka fè bon dòmi.
Second Example Sentence: Mwen santi tèt mwen pa kalm, sé pwoblem mwen ki ni.
Third Example Sentence: Sajès granmoun toujou ni verité adan’y.

Idiom (French Guianese Creole): Tout sa ki kléré pa lò.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Not everything that looks good is truly valuable.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Shared proverb across Caribbean Creoles adapted from French colonial sayings.
First Example Sentence: Pa fè konfyans tout moun, tout sa ki kléré pa lò.
Second Example Sentence: Yon bagay ka parèt bèl, mé i pa toujou bon.
Third Example Sentence: Granmanman té toujou di sa lè i té ka konsèy mwen.
